Table of Contents

Enum RuleFieldTarget

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Specifies the target field(s) of an article where a rule condition (e.g., keyword match, pattern search, or value comparison) is evaluated in the RSS reader's rule/filter engine.

public enum RuleFieldTarget

Fields

AllFields = 4

The condition must be true in all searched fields (usually title AND content).

Behavior:

  • Restrictive: term must appear in both title and content (or all targeted fields).
  • Reduces false positives significantly.
  • Internally applies logical AND across fields.
  • Higher performance cost than single-field targets.
AnyField = 5

The condition is satisfied if true in any of the searched fields (usually title OR content).

Behavior:

  • Inclusive: term found in title, content, or both.
  • Broadens matches — useful for general keyword discovery.
  • Internally applies logical OR across fields.
  • May increase false positives compared to narrower targets.
Author = 2

The condition is evaluated against the article's author name(s) or byline.

Behavior:

  • Matches single or multiple authors (comma-separated or array).
  • Common for author-specific rules (e.g., "from trusted journalist X").
  • Usually case-insensitive exact or partial match.
Categories = 3

The condition is evaluated against the article's assigned categories, tags, or labels.

Behavior:

  • Checks per-article tags or inherited feed categories.
  • Typically supports "contains tag X" or "has any of [X, Y]".
  • Fast if tags are stored/indexed as arrays or sets.
Content = 1

The condition is evaluated only against the article's main content/body text.

Behavior:

  • Checks full article text (or summary/excerpt if full content not available).
  • Slower than title-only but catches deeper context.
  • Useful for rules like "contains technical term" or "mentions specific company".
Title = 0

The condition is evaluated only against the article's title/headline.

Behavior:

  • Fastest evaluation — title is usually a short indexed field.
  • Most relevant for catching important topics from headlines.
  • Recommended default for keyword-based rules.

Remarks

This enumeration determines which part(s) of an article are inspected when applying a rule condition. It is used in combination with operators (contains, equals, starts with, regex match, etc.) and values to define precise matching criteria.

Typical usage in rule definitions:

  • RuleCondition { Field = RuleFieldTarget.Title, Operator = Contains, Value = "urgent" }
  • RuleCondition { Field = RuleFieldTarget.AllFields, Operator = MatchesRegex, Value = @"\bimportant\b" }

Behavioral impact and system considerations:

  • Choosing a narrow target (Title, Author) improves performance and reduces false positives compared to broader targets (AllFields).
  • Categories typically refers to the article's tags/labels or feed categories (exact semantics depend on whether tags are per-article or inherited from feed).
  • AllFields and AnyField perform searches across multiple parts of the article, usually title + content (and sometimes author/description if indexed).
  • Full-text search targets may be case-insensitive and support stemming/tokenization depending on the underlying search implementation.
  • When using AllFields or AnyField, the rule engine may apply different logical operators internally (AND for AllFields, OR for AnyField).

Business rules and recommendations:

  • Default recommended target for keyword rules: Title (fastest, most relevant for headlines).
  • Use Content for deeper semantic matches (e.g., body text contains specific phrases).
  • AllFields is convenient for broad keyword alerts but may increase false positives and slightly slow evaluation during bulk syncs.
  • AnyField is useful when users want to catch a term anywhere prominent without requiring it in every field.
  • For performance-critical environments, discourage widespread use of AllFields and AnyField on very large article sets unless indexed properly.
  • When exposing in UI, label clearly: "Title only", "Article body", "Author", "Tags/Categories", "Title and content (all must match)", "Title or content (any match)".
